briefing.opening: Good morning. I will now begin the climate briefing for January 1, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and International Warnings
sections.content: Today, news emerged from both domestic and international fronts that the scars of climate change-induced disasters remain deep, and new risks are emerging. Domestically, the aftermath of wildfires persists, and warnings have been issued about the increasing frequency of climate change-related disasters [2]. Internationally, water quality degradation has emerged as a new climate change risk in Nova Scotia, Canada [19], and in Jordan, the direct impacts of climate change are severely evident, with 70% of the olive harvest destroyed due to record heatwaves and drought [20].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Regional Spread of Domestic Carbon Neutrality Transition and Strengthening Education
sections.content: Concrete actions towards achieving carbon neutrality have been actively observed across various local governments and institutions in South Korea. Busan Metropolitan City has declared its inaugural year as a leading carbon-neutral city and an energy technology hub [4], while Seongbuk-gu has designated a basic environmental education center, officially launching its environmental education city initiative [5]. Gumi City aims to become a future-oriented industrial city, targeting carbon neutrality alongside its robotics, secondary battery, and advanced materials industries [6], and in Yecheon, a privately led 'Carbon-Neutral Village' experiment has concluded, presenting a model for practical daily life actions [7]. Furthermore, Sunchon National University is contributing to raising climate awareness among future generations by operating a Youth Climate Literacy Academy, linking climate change with Suncheon Bay [1].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Policies and Investments to Accelerate Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Climate Minister Kim Sung-hwan announced ambitious goals of an additional 200 million tons of carbon reduction and 100 GW of renewable energy by 2030 [15], and the Climate Ministry's Director-General for Renewable Energy Policy is pushing to completely redesign the renewable energy supply system from RPS (Renewable Portfolio Standard) to a bidding scheme [8]. Amidst calls for an 'all-in energy circular economy' for renewable energy transition [10], the designation of the nation's first distributed energy special zone heralds the dawn of a renewable energy 'pension era' [11]. The shutdown of Taean Thermal Power Unit 1 and its transition to new and renewable energy are accelerating this trend [13], while East-West Power's solar power operation strategy training and the installation of solar facilities by local governments and Samsung Display demonstrate concrete efforts to expand renewable energy [12, 14]. Meanwhile, South Korea, China, and Japan held a New Year's forum on carbon neutrality and energy transition, emphasizing the importance of regional cooperation [3].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Domestic and International Challenges of Energy Transition
sections.content: Alongside the energy transition process, several challenges are also emerging. Despite renewable energy being a global trend, criticism suggests that in South Korea, the 'price debate' continues to hinder progress, indicating a long road ahead [9]. Furthermore, with the prolonged 'chasm' of stagnant global electric vehicle demand, analyses suggest a 'bleak' outlook for the domestic battery industry in the new year [16]. In addition, controversy has arisen regarding the government's plan to develop a 10 GW renewable energy complex in Saemangeum, with critics arguing that 'Honam's power supply is already in surplus' [17], necessitating a cautious approach.

sections.title: ğŸŒ Strengthening Climate Policies and Expanding Public Participation in the International Community
sections.content: In the international community, efforts to strengthen policies and encourage public participation in combating climate change continue. In Europe, a petition movement is underway, strongly advocating for the mandatory zero-emission vehicle plan and urging action against climate change [18], reflecting civil society's active demands for climate policies. In the United States, progressive politicians and advocates are reframing climate policies as a form of economic populism, with emission reduction measures gaining popularity [21], demonstrating a new approach to enhance the social acceptability of climate policies.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted the reality of the climate crisis while also showcasing various domestic and international efforts to overcome it. This is a time that calls for sustained attention and action. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.title: Prolonged EV 'Chasm'... 'K-Battery' New Year Outlook 'Bleak'
articles.original_title: ì „ê¸°ì°¨ â€˜ìºì¦˜â€™ ì¥ê¸°í™”â€¦â€˜Kë°°í„°ë¦¬â€™ ìƒˆí•´ ì „ë§ë„ â€˜ì•”ìš¸â€™
articles.description: Amidst Chinese offensive... Successive contract terminations 'bad news'. Tightening belts and seeking new avenues with ESS. The outlook for the domestic battery industry is entirely bleak. The global EV chasm (stagnant demand) persists, and external factors such as delayed electrification policies in the US and the rapid advance of Chinese batteries are challenging. According to industry sources on the 1st, domestic battery manufacturers and material companies are busy building reserves and preparing crisis management measures in anticipation of a prolonged downturn. Their breakthroughs...

summary.phenomenon: As the global EV demand 'chasm' prolongs, the domestic battery industry faces a bleak outlook.
summary.cause: External environmental factors such as the persistent global EV chasm, delayed electrification policies in the US, and the rapid advance of Chinese battery manufacturers are complexly at play.
summary.outlook: Domestic battery manufacturers and material companies are expected to focus on building reserves and preparing crisis management measures in anticipation of a prolonged downturn, and will likely seek new avenues in the Energy Storage System (ESS) sector.

articles.title: Saemangeum 'Power Generation Facility' Plan... Controversy Over 'Honam Power Already in Surplus'
articles.original_title: ìƒˆë§Œê¸ˆ â€˜ë°œì „ ì„¤ë¹„â€™ ê³„íšì—â€¦â€œí˜¸ë‚¨ ì „ë ¥ ì´ë¯¸ ê³¼ì‰â€ ë…¼ë€
articles.description: Environmental groups state, 'Existing power generators are forcibly halted... Power market reform is a priority.' They also point out regional supply-demand disparities, saying, 'Companies in the Seoul metropolitan area should relocate to production sites.' Controversy has arisen over the government's plan to create a 10GW (gigawatt) renewable energy complex in Saemangeum to establish a 'national RE100 (100% of electricity used from renewable energy)' model. The government is accelerating the project, prioritizing large-scale investment attraction...

summary.phenomenon: Controversy has arisen regarding the government's plan to develop a 10GW renewable energy complex in Saemangeum, with critics arguing that the Honam region already has a surplus of electricity.
summary.cause: Environmental groups argue that power market reform should be prioritized, especially given that existing power generators in the Honam region are forcibly halted, and they point out disparities in electricity supply and demand between regions.
summary.outlook: While the government is accelerating the project by prioritizing large-scale investment attraction, environmental groups and others are demanding power market reform and the relocation of metropolitan area companies to production sites, suggesting the controversy is likely to continue.

articles.title: â€˜These trees may not surviveâ€™: Jordanâ€™s ancient olive harvest wilts under record-breaking heat
articles.description: Extreme heat and drought has destroyed 70% of Jordanâ€™s olive crop, endangering livelihoods of 80,000 families and a centuries-old traditionAbu Khaled al-Zoubi, 67, walks slowly through his orchard in Irbid, northern Jordan, his footsteps kicking up dust from the parched earth beneath centuries-old olive trees. He stops at a gnarled trunk, its bark split and peeling from months of unrelenting heat.He points out that the branches should be sagging under the weight of ripening fruit, but instead th

summary.phenomenon: In the Irbid region of northern Jordan, a record-breaking heatwave and drought have destroyed 70% of Jordan's olive crop.
summary.cause: Months of extreme heat and drought caused the olive tree bark to split and prevented proper fruit development, leading to significant damage.
summary.outlook: The reduction in olive harvest threatens the livelihoods of 80,000 families and a centuries-old olive cultivation tradition, with some olive trees potentially not surviving.

articles.title: From rent to utility bills: the politicians and advocates making climate policy part of the affordability agenda
articles.description: As the Trump administration derides climate policy as a â€˜scamâ€™, emissions-cutting measures are gaining popularityA group of progressive politicians and advocates are reframing emissions-cutting measures as a form of economic populism as the Trump administration derides climate policy as a â€œscamâ€ and fails to deliver on promises to tame energy costs and inflation.Climate politics were once cast as a test of moral resolve, calling on Americans to accept higher costs to avert environmental catastro

summary.phenomenon: In the United States, emissions-cutting measures are gaining popularity as progressive politicians and advocates reframe climate policy as a form of economic populism.
summary.cause: Amidst the Trump administration's criticism of climate policy as a 'scam' and its failure to deliver on promises to curb energy costs and inflation, new approaches to climate policy are being explored.
